text:

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Homework 0
text: In this blog, I will be explaining how to construct interesting data visualizations of the Palmer Penguins dataset using Python.

title: Homework 0
text: In this blog, I will be explaining how to construct interesting data visualizations of the Palmer Penguins dataset using Python.

title: Homework 0
text:
Loading Dataset
The dataset can be read into Python by running the following code

import pandas as pd
import numpy as np

title: Homework 0
text:
Bar Chart
In order to create data visualizations, we should first explore the dataset and understand the variables included as well as their relationship. For instance, I have noticed there are different categories of penguins and decided to investigate the distribution of penguins with bar chart.

#countplot function is used for showing the counts of observations in each categorical bin using bars
sns.countplot(x = 'Species', data = penguins)
plt.title('Distribution of Penguin Species')
plt.show()








From the bar chart, we can observe that Adelie has the greatest amount in the sample while Chinstrap has the least amount. However, this is not interesting. We could create more meaningful plots through the quantitative variables of each group.

title: Homework 0
text:
Scatterplot
As flipper length and body mass are both important components for a penguine, I am interested in whether there is any relationship between these two variables. To find such pattern between two quantitative variables, scatterplot is an useful tool.

#sns.scatterplot is a function from the Seaborn library in Python, used for creating scatterplots
sns.scatterplot(x='Flipper Length (mm)', y='Body Mass (g)', hue='Species', data=penguins)
plt.title('Flipper Length vs Body Mass by Species')
plt.show()








From the graph, we can oberve that there exists a positive correlations between flipper length and body mass in all three species, while the correlation strength could be explored further.

title: Homework 0
text:
Histogram
A histogram could also be used to represent the distribution of a numerical dataset, especially when we want to compare distribution of a variable across different groups. From the above scatterplot, We can see that both flipper length and body mass vary across different groups such that we can use histogram to find the distribution.

plt.figure(figsize=(14, 6))
plt.subplot(1, 2, 1) 
#sns.histplot is a function from the Seaborn library used to create histograms. 
sns.histplot(data=penguins, x='Body Mass (g)', hue='Species', element='step', palette='Set2')
plt.title('Histogram of Body Mass (g) by Species')
plt.ylabel('Frequency') 
plt.show()








From the histogram of body mass(g) by species, we can observe that Gentoo has greater body mass than Adelie and Chinstrap in general

plt.figure(figsize=(14, 6))
plt.subplot(1, 2, 1) 
#sns.histplot is a function from the Seaborn library used to create histograms. 
sns.histplot(data=penguins, x='Flipper Length (mm)', hue='Species', element='step', palette='Set2')
plt.title('Histogram of Flipper Length (mm) by Species')
plt.ylabel('Frequency') 
plt.show()








From the histogram of flipper length (mm) by species, we can observe that Gentoo has greater flipper length than Adelie and Chinstrap in general as well.

title: Homework 0
text:
Boxplot
In addition, we can also understand the distribution of data through boxplot, which is a standardized way of displaying the distribution based on a five-number summary: minimum, first quartile (Q1), median, third quartile (Q3), and maximum. For instance, we can investigate the culmen length of each group through box plot.

plt.figure(figsize=(6, 6))
#sns.boxplot is a function in the Seaborn library used to create boxplots. 
sns.boxplot(x='Species', y='Culmen Length (mm)', data=penguins, palette='Set1')
plt.title('Boxplot of Culmen Length (mm) by Species')
plt.show()








From the boxplot, we can observe that Chinstrap has the greatest median among three species such that we could conclude that Chinstrap has the greatest culmen length compared to the other two species. Meanwhile, Adelie has the least median such that it has the least culmen length overall.

title: Homework 0
text:
Conclusion
In this tutorial, we explored various ways to visualize the Palmer Penguins dataset. By employing different types of plots, we gained valuable insights into the data. Remember, the key to effective data visualization lies in choosing the right type of plot that best represents the data’s story!

title: myblog
text:
import pandas as pd
import sqlite3

# Load the data files
temps_df = pd.read_csv('temps.csv')
stations_df = pd.read_csv('station-metadata.csv')
countries_df = pd.read_csv('country-codes.csv')

# Create a SQLite database
conn = sqlite3.connect('temps.db')

def prepare_df(df):
    return df

# temperatures table 
df_iter = pd.read_csv('temps.csv', chunksize=100000)
for i, df in enumerate(df_iter):
    df = prepare_df(df)
    df.to_sql("temperatures", conn, if_exists="replace" if i == 0 else "append", index=False)

# stations table
stations_df = prepare_df(stations_df)
stations_df.to_sql("stations", conn, if_exists="replace", index=False)

# countries table
countries_df = prepare_df(countries_df)
countries_df.to_sql("countries", conn, if_exists="replace", index=False)

cursor = conn.cursor()
cursor.execute("SELECT name FROM sqlite_master WHERE type='table'")
tables_created = cursor.fetchall()

# Close the database connection
conn.close()



from climate_database import query_climate_database
import inspect

# Print the source code of the function
print(inspect.getsource(query_climate_database))

df = query_climate_database(db_file = "temps.db",
                            country = "India", 
                            year_begin = 1980, 
                            year_end = 2020,
                            month = 1)

print(df)

def query_climate_database(db_file, country, year_begin, year_end, month):
    
    # Open a new connection to the specified database file
    conn = sqlite3.connect(db_file)
    
    # SQL command
    cmd = f"""
    SELECT 
        S.NAME, 
        S.LATITUDE, 
        S.LONGITUDE, 
        C.NAME as Country, 
        T.Year, 
        T.Month, 
        T.Temp
    FROM 
        stations S
    INNER JOIN 
        temperatures T ON T.ID = S.ID
    INNER JOIN 
        countries C ON S.ID LIKE C.'FIPS 10-4' || '%'
    WHERE 
        C.NAME = ? AND 
        T.Year BETWEEN ? AND ? AND 
        T.Month = ? AND
        T.Temp IS NOT NULL
    """
    
    # Execute the query and store the results in a pandas DataFrame
    df = pd.read_sql_query(cmd, conn, params=(country, year_begin, year_end, month))
    
    # Close the database connection
    conn.close()
    
    return df

[3152 rows x 7 columns]



#3. Write a Geographic Scatter Function for Yearly Temperature Increases
import plotly.express as px
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression

def compute_linear_regression_coefficient(x, y):
    # Compute the coefficient (slope) of a linear regression model
    model = LinearRegression()
    model.fit(x.reshape(-1, 1), y)
    return model.coef_[0]

def temperature_coefficient_plot(db_file, country, year_begin, year_end, month, min_obs, **kwargs):
    # Connect to the database
    conn = sqlite3.connect(db_file)
    
    # Fetch the data
    df = pd.read_sql_query(
        f"""
        SELECT 
            S.NAME, 
            S.LATITUDE, 
            S.LONGITUDE, 
            T.YEAR, 
            T.VALUE{month} as Temp
        FROM 
            stations S
        JOIN 
            temperatures T ON T.ID = S.ID
        JOIN 
            countries C ON SUBSTR(T.ID, 1, 2) = C.'FIPS 10-4'
        WHERE 
            C.NAME = ? AND 
            T.YEAR BETWEEN ? AND ? AND 
            T.VALUE{month} IS NOT NULL
        """,
        conn, params=(country, year_begin, year_end))

    # Close the connection
    conn.close()
    
    # Ensure that we only consider stations with at least `min_obs` years of data
    counts = df.groupby('NAME').size()
    valid_stations = counts[counts >= min_obs].index
    df = df[df['NAME'].isin(valid_stations)]

    # Calculate the yearly temperature change coefficient for each station
    df['Year'] = df['Year'].astype(int)
    df['Temp'] = df['Temp'].astype(float) / 100  # assuming the temperature is in centi-degrees
    coef_df = df.groupby('NAME').apply(lambda x: compute_linear_regression_coefficient(x['Year'].values, x['Temp'].values))

    # Prepare the dataframe for plotting
    plot_df = df[['NAME', 'LATITUDE', 'LONGITUDE']].drop_duplicates()
    plot_df = plot_df.set_index('NAME').join(coef_df.rename('Temp_Change')).reset_index()
    
    # Create the scatter plot
    fig = px.scatter_mapbox(
        plot_df,
        lat="LATITUDE",
        lon="LONGITUDE",
        color="Temp_Change",
        hover_name="NAME",
        hover_data={"Temp_Change": ":.2f"},
        center={"lat": plot_df['LATITUDE'].mean(), "lon": plot_df['LONGITUDE'].mean()},
        **kwargs
    )

    # Add colorbar title and center the color at 0
    fig.update_layout(
        coloraxis_colorbar=dict(
            title="Yearly Temperature Change(°C/year)",
            ticks="outside",
            tickvals=[coef_df.min(), 0, coef_df.max()],
            ticktext=[f"{coef_df.min():.2f}", "0", f"{coef_df.max():.2f}"]
        ),
        title=f"Estimate of Yearly Change in Temperature of Stations in {country} in month {month} from {year_begin} to {year_end}"
    )

    return fig

color_map = px.colors.diverging.RdGy_r  # choose a colormap


#India
fig = temperature_coefficient_plot(
    db_file="temps.db",
    country="India",
    year_begin=1980,
    year_end=2020,
    month=1,
    min_obs=10,
    zoom=3,
    mapbox_style="carto-positron",
    color_continuous_scale=color_map
)

fig.show()


#Belgium 
fig = temperature_coefficient_plot(
    db_file="temps.db",
    country="Belgium",
    year_begin=1980,
    year_end=2020,
    month=1,
    min_obs=10,
    zoom=5,
    mapbox_style="carto-positron",
    color_continuous_scale=color_map
)

fig.show()


#4. Visualization
import plotly.express as px

def query_annual_temp_distribution(db_file, country):
    conn = sqlite3.connect(db_file)
    query = """
    SELECT S.NAME, AVG(T.VALUE1 + T.VALUE2 + T.VALUE3 + T.VALUE4 + T.VALUE5 + T.VALUE6 + T.VALUE7 + T.VALUE8 + T.VALUE9 + T.VALUE10 + T.VALUE11 + T.VALUE12)/12 as AnnualAvgTemp
    FROM stations S
    JOIN temperatures T ON T.ID = S.ID
    JOIN countries C ON SUBSTR(T.ID, 1, 2) = C.'FIPS 10-4'
    WHERE C.NAME = ?
    GROUP BY S.NAME
    """
    df = pd.read_sql_query(query, conn, params=(country,))
    conn.close()
    return df



import plotly.express as px

def visualize_annual_avg_temp(df, country):
    # Creating a bar chart using Plotly
    fig = px.bar(df, x='NAME', y='AnnualAvgTemp', title=f'Annual Average Temperature at Each Station in {country}',
                 labels={'NAME': 'Station Name', 'AnnualAvgTemp': 'Annual Average Temperature (°C)'})
    
    # Enhancing the layout
    fig.update_layout(xaxis_title='Station Name', 
                      yaxis_title='Annual Average Temperature (°C)', 
                      xaxis_tickangle=-45)

    # Show the figure
    return fig

db_file = 'temps.db'
country = 'Belgium'
df = query_annual_temp_distribution(db_file, country)
visualize_annual_avg_temp(df, country)

Unable to display output for mime type(s): application/vnd.plotly.v1+json




def plot_annual_temp_distribution(db_file, country):
    df = query_annual_temp_distribution(db_file, country)
    fig = px.box(df, y='AnnualAvgTemp', title=f'Distribution of Annual Average Temperatures Across Stations in {country}')
    fig.update_layout(yaxis_title='Annual Average Temperature')
    return fig

fig = plot_annual_temp_distribution("temps.db", "India")
fig.show()

Unable to display output for mime type(s): application/vnd.plotly.v1+json



import plotly.express as px

def visualize_annual_temp_distribution_3d(df, country):
    fig = px.scatter_3d(df, 
                        x='LATITUDE', 
                        y='LONGITUDE', 
                        z='AnnualAvgTemp', 
                        color='AnnualAvgTemp',
                        hover_name='NAME',
                        title=f'3D View of Annual Average Temperature Distribution for {country}')
    fig.update_layout(coloraxis_colorbar=dict(title="Annual Avg Temp (°C)"))
    fig.show()
df = query_annual_temp_distribution('temps.db', 'India')
fig = visualize_annual_temp_distribution_3d(df, 'India')
fig.show()

ValueError: Value of 'x' is not the name of a column in 'data_frame'. Expected one of ['NAME', 'AnnualAvgTemp'] but received: LATITUDE



import plotly.express as px

def visualize_annual_temp_facets(df, country):
    # Make sure column names match those in the DataFrame
    fig = px.scatter(df, x='NAME', y='AnnualAvgTemp', facet_col='Year', 
                     color='Region', title=f'Annual Average Temperature for Stations in {country}')
    
    fig.update_layout(facet_col_wrap=4)  # Adjust the number of columns per row in the facet wrap
    fig.update_xaxes(tickangle=-45)  # Rotate the x-axis labels for better readability
    return fig

# Assuming 'query_annual_temp_distribution' function is defined as before and 'df' is the DataFrame obtained
# Also assuming 'df' includes a 'Year' column and 'Region' column which categorizes stations into different regions
df = query_annual_temp_distribution('temps.db', 'India')
fig = visualize_annual_temp_facets(df, 'India')
fig.show()

ValueError: Value of 'facet_col' is not the name of a column in 'data_frame'. Expected one of ['NAME', 'AnnualAvgTemp'] but received: Year
